properties.name: Historic Cotton Warehouses Cluster 1
properties.description: Historic cotton warehouses near Quaker Ave & 15th St. Influenced early commercial development and street layout.

properties.name: Historic Cotton Warehouses Cluster 2
properties.description: A secondary warehouse cluster near Quaker Ave and 19th St that expanded the city’s early cotton-based economy and reinforced industrial land-use along key arterial corridors. The presence of these warehouses catalyzed commercial intensification along 19th St, shaping it into a mixed commercial-industrial corridor rather than a purely residential street. This cluster contributed to a heterogeneous urban pattern—where industrial parcels intermingled with early storefronts—creating one of Lubbock’s foundational hybrid land-use zones.

properties.name: Modern Industrial Area 1
properties.description: Industrial parks and warehouses along the historical railroad corridor. Continues the legacy of cotton-based commerce into modern industry.

properties.name: Modern Industrial Area 2
properties.description: A major contemporary industrial cluster east of downtown near Loop 289, illustrating Lubbock’s transition from rail-dependent industry to highway-oriented logistics. Its placement along the loop shows how the city’s industrial geography shifted outward as automotive freight replaced rail as the dominant mode of movement. This decentralization promoted low-density industrial land-use patterns, expanded the urban footprint, and established a ring-based industrial morphology centered on high-mobility roadways rather than the historic core.

properties.name: Historic Cotton Storage along Rail
properties.description: Smaller storage areas adjacent to historic rail spurs near downtown. Shaped early industrial zoning and nearby street alignments.
